content.description: Very good route. This should have more stars in Marty's guidebook, as it's better than Rocky, which gets 4 stars.
content.location: 2nd route from the right on the Lower Fifth Canyon Wall

content.description: Easy start with more technical climbing as you continue.  The 5th bolt can be a bit tricky coming off a slab section.  The finish is a bit thin until you get to the anchors.

From The Northwest Passage Guide Book:

Belay from a single bolt next to a large flake. Go down a bit then move up right to the broken ledge. Angle back left along sharpe ledges to a smooth wall. Up to the small roof. Reach into the hand jam slot then back to the edge and onto a resting ledge. Move out left onto the upper face and up to LO chains.

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)
content.location: Second route from the left in the Lower Fifth Canyon. To the right of Hang It Out and to the left of Betty Cragger.

content.description: The crux 10 ft. off the ground. take care at the first bolt as it's a pretty tricky clip. This climb is rated 10d in Marty's quide. A tricky traverse across a thin slab followed by some very reachy moves.
content.location: Far right route on Lower Fifth Canyon Wall.

content.description: A steep start with the crux low down leads to very fun climbing in a dihedral. It feels more like 10c if you miss the hidden hold around the 2nd bolt. Well protected, safe lead.
content.location: This is the route in the obvious dihedral at the left end of the Lower Fifth Canyon

content.description: Follow the bolts through cool edges and a hard finish. Bolts to chains.

From The Northwest Passage Guide Book:

The one starts to the Right, where the cliff begins to be capped by a large roof. Steep bulges and a lot of traversing around roofs. This is a real rope drag management challenge. long draws help and double ropes work great. The route is best cleaning by following it. There is now a halfway belay at the end of the traverse.

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)

Harquebus starts in a steep corner and will have you thinking right off the bat. You'll move onto the arete and find another crux in a corner just below the top. Moving to the last bolt is very spooky because you're moving over a bulge on slopers with your forearms flamed. Be aware that if you blow the last clip the fall has some nasty potential, but two climbers I know have whipped from here and threaded the needle and taken a clean fall right into the corner.
content.location: look for the nice clean right facing corner about 40 feet in from the right end of the wall. It's just to the right of Blunderbuss.

content.description:
From The Northwest Passage Guide Book:

The object is to get into the dramatic, hanging, left-facing dihedral-by traversing in under the roof from the right. Climb the bolts of Pack It Out to the resting ledge where the roof starts. Start good natural pro from here. Traverse L fairly sensationally and swing into the dihedral. Fun for a while then a crux bulge to a  shallow groove (tricky but OK pro).

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)
content.location: Farthest left route in Lower Fifth Canyon. To the left of Pack It Out.

content.description:
A groovy-robby line right of a big roof.

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)

From The Northwest Passage Guide Book:

Starts on the lowest part of the buttress, just right of Country music trademark. Nice little dyne, some balance and a steep right traverse up high to avoid the chop blocks.

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)
content.location: To the right of Little Bit Country Music and to the left of Little Bit Rock and Roll.

content.description: Use the overhanging corner start for Pack in Pack out.  Continue up left over easy terrain to the thin crack in the yellow headwall. Bust over the bulge to the chains.
content.protection: Micro nuts protect thin crack.  Theres a bolt in the face that makes this route safe.  Thin nuts to 3"

content.description: Check this route out! This is my favorite climb at Post Falls. I won't give any beta on the low crux, but it's fun to figure out. Tricky moves over a bulge to the second clip. After the steep section, you move into a nice dihedral that will have you stemming in a very cool, exposed position.
content.location: Look for the clean right-facing corner that is Harquebus, 40 feet from the right end of the wall. Blunderbuss is the next climb to the left.

content.description: Fairly clear cut route with only a couple tough moves consistent with the rating.  Good warm up (actually the only one) for the surrounding climbs.

Do we really need drilled holes in the rock to tell us where we can find a trad route? WTF?

This fun route starts in the overhanging crack. Take the obvious route from here, The climbing is very chill, easier than it looks, and quite good.
content.protection: A small rack to 1" will do fine. finish at chains
content.location: Look for the 3 drilled holes in the shape of a triangle below the obvious crack. There are two of these marks. Once again, WTF? Country Music is the route on the right. The left side route sucks as far as I could tell. It peters out into loose choss with no pro up above.

content.description:
A black, broken mossy crack with a short but puppy bulging crux.

(Thanks to Rusty Baillie, Maxine Whiteside, Andrea, The Gifts and Marty Bland for these route descriptions and beta photos.)
